Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..raw_text: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928)
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..proposition: General negligence authorities including Donoghue v. Stevenson, [1932] AC 562 (establishing duty concepts), Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N.Y. 339 (1928) (proximate cause), and other foundational negligence authorities as applied in Massachusetts jurisprudence;
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..case_name: Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..support_reasoning: The proposition cites Palsgraf as a foundational negligence authority specifically for proximate cause concepts. In this opinion, Cardozo reframes the analysis in terms of duty and the scope of risk, but he explicitly distinguishes questions of duty from questions of proximate cause and addresses the limits of liability based on foreseeability and the ‘range of apprehension.’ This case is widely recognized and used as a leading authority on proximate cause (and related duty/foreseeability limits), so citing it for proximate cause concepts in negligence is accurate, even in a Massachusetts context.
Palsgraf v. Long Island R.R. Co., 248 N..relevant_excerpt: “The range of reasonable apprehension is at times a question for the court, and at times, if varying inferences are possible, a question for the jury… Negligence, like risk, is thus a term of relation… If the harm was not willful, he must show that the act as to him had possibilities of danger so many and apparent as to entitle him to be protected against the doing of it though the harm was unintended… The law of causation, remote or proximate, is thus foreign to the case before us.”
